- Experts recommend using the N-Rate Calculator and Precision Conservation Management program to maximize profits rather than just yields, by finding the optimal nitrogen application rate.
- The Commodity Week and Closing Market Report radio programs provide market updates for farmers.

Recommendations:
- Use the N-Rate Calculator and Precision Conservation Management to optimize nitrogen application and protect water quality while maximizing profits.
- Stay informed on weather and market conditions through radio programs like Commodity Week and Closing Market Report.

items.title: Why Attention Matters More Than Response for Advertisers
items.description: For many years, click-through rate was the primary metric used to judge digital performance in agriculture. Today, it no longer tells the full story. Farmers are searching differently, using AI-assisted tools, voice search and quick-scan platforms that often answer their questions without the need to click at all. With this shift, the true indicator of […] The post Why Attention Matters More Than Response for Advertisers appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
Farmers are increasingly using AI-assisted tools, voice search, and quick-scan platforms that allow them to find information without needing to click. The true indicator of content effectiveness is now attention time - how long a user spends meaningfully engaged with the content.

AgWeb.com recently underwent a redesign to increase user attention and engagement. The results show:
- 54% increase in readers reaching 75% of an article
- 21% increase in readers reaching 90% of an article
- 33% increase in daily article pageviews per mobile user

The article cites data that 79% of online users scan content rather than reading word-for-word, and most only absorb around 28% of page text. AgWeb's redesign aimed to simplify layouts and guide deeper engagement.

Attention time is a better metric than CTR because it shows if users stayed with the content, scrolled with purpose, consumed multiple articles, and were in an active, focused mindset. High-attention environments deliver stronger results for advertisers, as their brand is present during engaged moments.

The improvements on AgWeb are said to directly translate to more value for brands, providing more time with content, more content consumed per session, higher quality impressions, and better alignment with how farmers search today. The article concludes that attention, not just clicks, should be the priority metric for ag marketers.

items.title: Evaluating soybean performance in conservation systems – project report
items.description: You can also read the article in Portuguese and Spanish Introduction Recent dust storm events in central Illinois and across the Midwest have renewed attention on soil conservation, especially after the tragic May 2023 event near Springfield that caused an 80-vehicle pileup, eight fatalities, and dozens of injuries. These incidents highlight that soil loss is not only an agronomic issue but also a public safety and environmental concern. Reduced tillage and cover crops are well-established pract
items.summary: Twitter Facebook LinkedIn The Bulletin Evaluating soybean performance in conservation systems – project report Giovani Preza FontesFederico Rolle and John Jones Department of Crop Sciences Unive...

items.title: The February Greenhouse: What to Grow Now
items.description: When winter is halfway over, growing out of the elements is the only option for many farmers. Here, we share how to use a greenhouse to grow what the climate doesn‚Äôt allow and keep the revenue flowing. The post The February Greenhouse: What to Grow Now appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Greenhouses can provide a protected environment to start growing plants early for the spring market. 

Key points:
- Greenhouses trap thermal heat to warm plants, with features like vents, structures, and climate control systems. Different types include modular plastic, low tunnels, cold frames, and larger designer greenhouses.
- In February, good greenhouse crops to start include tomatoes, peppers, brassicas (kale, cabbage, cauliflower), lettuces, potatoes, onions, and flowers.
- Tomatoes and peppers benefit from the early start and warmth of a greenhouse, with ideal temperatures around 50¬∞F (10¬∞C).
- Brassicas and lettuces can be grown to get an early spring harvest, protected from pests and frost.
- Potatoes and onions also do well with a greenhouse start to get a head start on the season.
- Flowers that take a long time to sprout, like lisianthus and dahlias, are good candidates for greenhouse growing to ensure spring blooms.

The article provides guidance for farmers on how to utilize different greenhouse types and what crops to prioritize for early greenhouse planting in the month of February.

items.title: Farm Journal and Hass Avocado Board Launch The Avocado Conference
items.description: Kansas City, MO., (January 28, 2026) ‚Äì  The Packer, the produce industry‚Äôs premier publication from Farm Journal, announced the launch of The Avocado Conference, a first-of-its-kind international event gathering every segment of the U.S. avocado supply chain. The inaugural event is set for Nov. 18-20, 2026, at the Hilton San Diego Bayfront. The conference directly […] The post Farm Journal and Hass Avocado Board Launch The Avocado Conference appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- The Packer, a publication from Farm Journal, is launching The Avocado Conference, a new international event for the U.S. avocado supply chain.
- The inaugural event is scheduled for November 18-20, 2026, in San Diego, California.
- The conference is a collaboration between Farm Journal and the Hass Avocado Board (HAB) to strengthen the global avocado industry and promote Hass avocados as America's preferred healthy food.
- The conference aims to bring together all segments of the avocado supply chain, including producers, exporters, importers, packers, retail and foodservice buyers, and other industry partners.
- The program will cover topics such as global avocado production and trade, retail and foodservice market insights, consumer and shopper trends, avocado marketing programs, and the role of the Hass Avocado Board in expanding avocado demand.
- The conference is expected to provide valuable data-driven insights, facilitate collaboration, and promote strategic alignment within the avocado industry to drive sustainable growth in avocado consumption across the U.S. market.
- Key stakeholders attending the event will include growers, packers, importers, exporters, retailers, foodservice buyers, and various industry service providers.

items.title: New Training Materials Available for Iowa Pesticide Applicators
items.description: The Iowa State University Pesticide Safety Education Program has revised several applicator manuals and exams to reflect the updated pesticide applicator certification and training rules implemented by the Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship on Jan. 1.
items.summary:
Key Summary:

The Iowa State University Pesticide Safety Education Program has updated several applicator manuals and exams to align with new pesticide applicator certification and training rules implemented by the Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship on January 1, 2026. 

The updated training materials, available for purchase through the ISU Extension Store, include the Iowa Core Manual (CS445) and an informational update in the Private Pesticide Applicator Manual (CS1). New exams based on the revised core manual are now available at all Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship test sites.

For more information, contact Betsy Danielson, Pesticide Safety Education Extension Specialist at Iowa State University, at betsydan@iastate.edu.

items.title: Stop Chasing Leads. Start Designing the Right Offer.
items.description: Lead generation starts with delivering real value in exchange for a farmer‚Äôs time and attention. The CTA and offer you choose shape not only how many leads you capture, but how qualified, motivated and purchase-ready those prospects become. When you shift your mindset from what you want to collect to what farmers genuinely need in […] The post Stop Chasing Leads. Start Designing the Right Offer. appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
The key points are:

- Lead generation should focus on delivering real value to farmers in exchange for their time and attention, rather than just collecting information.
- The call-to-action (CTA) and offer you choose shape not only how many leads are captured, but also how qualified, motivated and ready to purchase those prospects become.
- Shifting the mindset from what you want to collect to what farmers genuinely need is crucial for effective lead generation.

items.title: Jan 23 | Weather Update and Market Review
items.description: Winter has come back with a vengeance after a temporary pause. Average temperatures this week ranged from the low teens in northern Illinois to the mid-20s in southern Illinois, between 4 and 8 degrees below normal statewide. Nighttime low temperatures this week regularly dipped into the single digits, if not below zero, including -5 degrees in Rockford and -2 in Aurora. The wind was also a factor, pushing wind chill values close to -20 on a few days.…
items.summary:
Temperatures this week were 4-8 degrees below normal, with nighttime lows reaching as low as -5¬∞F in Rockford and -2¬∞F in Aurora. The cold and windy weather resulted in wind chill values near -20¬∞F on some days. 

Precipitation has also been very limited, with only around 0.5 inches in northeast Illinois and virtually no rain in southwest Illinois over the past 7 days. January to date has been the 4th driest on record in Carbondale and 10th driest in Charleston, with less than 0.5 inches so far.

The cold weather is expected to continue for at least another week, with most of northern Illinois staying below freezing for the rest of the month. However, a strong winter storm is predicted to hit southern Illinois this weekend, potentially bringing 8-12 inches of snow south of I-64, with some isolated heavier snowfall.

The article also covers the latest Commodity Week radio programming, which featured panelists Chip Nellinger of Blue Reef Agri-Marketing, Brian Stark from The Andersons, and Arlan Suderman with StoneX discussing the commodity markets. The Closing Market Report also airs daily on WILL AM580.

items.title: Brand and Content Discoverability Is the New Battleground in Ag Marketing
items.description: The world is searching for information a bit differently these days. Gone are the days of winning the click (traditional SEO). The game now is centered on winning brand authority and trust (modern AEO, answer engine optimization). In a world now crowded with ‚ÄúAI slop,‚Äù brands will only cut through by growing brand authority and […] The post Brand and Content Discoverability Is the New Battleground in Ag Marketing appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
Key points:

- The focus has shifted from traditional SEO (search engine optimization) to modern AEO (answer engine optimization), where brands need to build authority and trust to cut through the "AI slop".
- Farmers are increasingly using AI-powered platforms like ChatGPT, Google's AI Overviews, and mobile voice search to find information, and brands need to be present in these new discovery channels to avoid becoming "invisible".
- At Farm Journal, the authors are observing and adapting to this shift in discoverability, which should prompt all ag marketers to reevaluate their 2026 strategy.
- An answer-driven content strategy and amplifying trusted voices will be more important than ever in this new AEO era.
- Discoverability is now about winning the citation, brand mention, and trusted source reference to build brand authority, even in zero-click moments.

items.title: Forest Farming: Why it Might Make Sense for Your Land
items.description: Also called agroforestry, forest farming is a great way to work within your environmental parameters and utilize the tree canopy to produce more for your farm. Especially for those who live in forested areas, this practice enhances farm output without compromising the ecosystem. The post Forest Farming: Why it Might Make Sense for Your Land appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Key points:
- Agroforestry originated in Brazil's tropical rainforests and combines crops with selective lumber production.
- It involves thinning a forest to allow the best conditions for crops like native ornamentals, fungi, fruit, timber, and forest food crops to grow in the understory.
- Benefits include improved water/soil quality, carbon storage (up to 22 lbs/year), habitat for beneficial species, and access to specialty crop markets.
- Farms with existing forest or riparian areas are best suited for agroforestry. It can be implemented on small scales.
- Considerations include managing invasive tree species, understanding local market demands, and navigating regulations around wild plant harvesting.
- Farmers should consult their agricultural extension office to develop a forest management plan.

The article provides a comprehensive overview of the forest farming approach, its advantages, suitable land types, and key implementation steps - giving farmers a thorough understanding without needing to read the full original article.

items.title: Jan 16 | Weather Update and Market Review
items.description: The second week of the year brought a fleeting taste of spring, with average temperatures between the mid-30s to upper 40s; 8 to 12 degrees above normal. Some of the more impressive daytime high temperatures this week included 69 in Kaskaskia and 68 in Carbondale. January to date has been 7 to 12 degrees above normal statewide, and has been a top 10 warmest first half of January on record in most parts of the state.…
items.summary:
The past week saw above-normal temperatures, ranging from the mid-30s to upper 40s, 8-12 degrees above normal. Some locations reached highs of 69¬∞F and 68¬∞F. January to date has been 7-12 degrees warmer than normal, ranking in the top 10 warmest first halves of January on record for most of the state.

Despite the warm weather, precipitation has been lacking, with 7-day totals ranging from 0.1 inch in southeast Illinois to 0.75 inch in central Illinois. January to date has been 0.5-1 inch drier than normal, except for 1-3 inches of rain in a narrow area between Peoria and Chicago. This winter has been slightly wetter than normal in northeast Illinois, slightly drier in central/western Illinois, and much drier (top 5 driest on record) in southern Illinois.

Looking ahead, a cold front will move in this weekend, with highs only reaching the 20s in northern Illinois and above freezing in southern Illinois. Monday will see single-digit temperatures. Little precipitation is expected, mostly light snow. Colder than normal temperatures are forecast for the first week of February.

The article also provides an overview of the weekly WILL radio programming, including the Commodity Week and Closing Market Report programs featuring analysts Logan Kimmel, Jim McCormick, and Mike Zuzolo.

items.title: Getting Started with Spray Drones in Iowa: A Practical Guide
items.description: Spray drones are increasingly being evaluated by Iowa farmers as an additional tool for crop input application. When used appropriately, these systems can provide flexibility for timely applications, reduce fi
items.summary:
When used properly, they can provide flexibility for timely applications, reduce field traffic, and improve access to difficult areas. However, adopting spray drone technology requires careful consideration of regulations, training, insurance, and management practices.

Key points:
- Spray drones can be useful for applications when soils are too wet, in tall crops, to reduce compaction, and for targeted/site-specific applications.
- Regulatory requirements include FAA Part 107 Remote Pilot Certificate, FAA Part 137 Certification for aerial pesticide application, and Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship (IDALS) licensing.
- Farmers need insurance coverage including chemical liability, general liability, and hull/physical damage.
- Equipment factors to consider include spray tank capacity, battery life, nozzle options, and GPS guidance features.
- Proper training is essential for safe and effective operation, including calibration, weather monitoring, and maintenance.
- Farmers are encouraged to start on a limited scale and compare results to conventional methods.
- Resources available include Iowa State University programs, licensed dealers, and IDALS guidance.

Spray drone technology continues to evolve, with ongoing improvements in payload, automation, and data integration. Careful evaluation and gradual adoption are recommended for Iowa farmers.

items.title: Double-crop Soybean Management Practices – Project Report
items.description: You can also read the article in Portuguese and Spanish Introduction There is a growing interest in wheat/soybean double-cropping systems in Illinois, extending into parts of central Illinois where wheat acreage has been limited in recent decades. USDA-NASS survey estimates that 60-80% of Illinois wheat acres are double-cropped with soybeans. Implementing this system in central and northern Illinois has been constrained primarily by low wheat acreage and by later wheat harvest, which often delay
items.summary:
Key findings:

- Double-crop soybean yields averaged 55.7 bu/acre in 2024 and 47.8 bu/acre in 2025.
- Full-season soybean varieties (MG 3.6-3.8) yielded 4% (2.1 bu/acre) more than early-maturing varieties (MG 3.0-3.2) across treatments.
- Seeding rate response differed by maturity group - early varieties yielded best at 252,000 seeds/acre, while full-season peaked at 207,000 seeds/acre.
- Starter fertilizer (26 lb N, 11 lb S) increased yields by 1.4 bu/acre (2.6%) in 2024 but not in 2025 or on average.

The research was conducted by the University of Illinois Crop Sciences Dept. in collaboration with the Illinois Agricultural Experiment Station, Illinois Fertilizer & Chemical Association, and a Piatt County producer. More trials across locations are ongoing to strengthen regional recommendations for double-crop soybean management.

items.title: The 9 Best Flowers and Vegetables to Winter Sow
items.description: For farms in colder areas, starting seeds in time for the spring market requires a significant amount of time and indoor space. Winter sowing is a method that can be done outdoors and gives seedlings a stronger constitution as they mature. Here, we share plants that thrive when winter sown. The post The 9 Best Flowers and Vegetables to Winter Sow appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Winter sowing involves starting seeds in containers like milk jugs or plastic bags and placing them outdoors, where the cold, moist conditions help the seeds break dormancy. This results in hardier transplants that mature sooner.

The best vegetables for winter sowing include hardy greens like kale and cabbage, as well as spinach, onions, and leafy greens. Kale, cabbage, and spinach can handle cold well even in their early stages. Onions, especially bulbing onions, benefit from the long maturation period. Leafy greens like kale, collards, and chard are also excellent choices.

For flowers, the article recommends perennials like pansies, echinacea, snapdragons, larkspur, and scabiosa. These flowers often need a period of cold stratification, which is provided by the winter sowing method.

The article provides specific variety recommendations for some of the vegetables and flowers, such as 'Carex' cabbage, 'Avon' spinach, and different types of snapdragons. It also discusses the ideal growing conditions for long-day, short-day, and intermediate-day onions.

Overall, the winter sowing method allows farmers to get a head start on the growing season and produce hardier, more mature plants come spring. The article emphasizes the benefits of this technique for maximizing profits and productivity.

items.title: 5 Agri-Environmental Strategies that Prevent Species Loss
items.description: On today‚Äôs farms, ecologically-friendly practices are on the rise. Using agri-environmental strategies, farmers prevent environmental degradation, preserving natural spaces and the species that live in them. The post 5 Agri-Environmental Strategies that Prevent Species Loss appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
However, there are several agri-environmental strategies farmers can employ to support biodiversity:

1. Prairie Strips: Planting 10-25% of farmland in prairie strips can attract beneficial predators, improve soil nutrients, and boost yields by supporting pollinators and pest-controlling insects.

2. Low Tilling: Reducing tillage and using cover crops can improve soil structure and support greater biodiversity above and below ground.

3. Regenerative Grazing: Rotating livestock and using native plants, fire, and mowing can maintain healthy pastures and provide habitat for local species, especially in areas with prairie or forest ecosystems. 

4. Integrated Pest Management (IPM): Attracting beneficial insects through diverse plantings and cultural practices can reduce reliance on harmful pesticides.

5. Conservation Easements: Partnering with land trusts to establish conservation easements can protect natural resources and provide tax benefits for farmers with large landholdings.

Implementing these strategies, even partially, can have significant positive impacts on biodiversity and farm productivity by working with natural systems rather than against them. Experts emphasize that farming is as much for humans as it is a constant reminder of the laws of the natural world, and the more farmers can see their land as part of a larger ecosystem, the more sustainable their agriculture can become.

items.title: 2026 Crop Advantage Series Meetings to Be Held at 12 Locations in January
items.description: AMES, Iowa ‚Äì The 2026 Crop Advantage Series will take place at 12 locations across the state Jan. 6‚Äì29. Each meeting will feature tailored topics selected based on local growing conditions and challenges, presented by Iowa State University Extension and Outreach specialists.
items.summary:
The 2026 Crop Advantage Series will be held at 12 locations across Iowa from January 6 to 29. The meetings will feature topics tailored to local growing conditions and challenges, presented by Iowa State University Extension and Outreach specialists.

Key details:
- Locations: Sioux Center, Storm Lake, Burlington, Mason City, Estherville, Waterloo, Davenport, Ankeny, Atlantic, Iowa City, Le Mars, Carroll
- Dates: January 6-29, 2026
- Early-bird registration: $75 until the week before each meeting
- Late/on-site registration: $100
- Includes refreshments, lunch, certified crop advisor credits, and access to resources
- Private pesticide applicator recertification available for an additional $30 fee

Topics to be covered include crop market and climate outlooks for 2026, nitrates and drinking water, profitable nutrient management, southern rust, transition planning, and robots/drones.

The goal is to provide farmers and crop production professionals with the latest research-based information to help them make informed decisions for the upcoming growing season. Registration and more information is available on the Crop Advantage Series website.

items.title: Farm Journal Announces 2026 Top Producer Award Finalists
items.description: Outstanding producers from California, Kansas, Ohio, Oregon and Wisconsin will be recognized for excellence, leadership and innovation. Kansas City, Mo., (Dec. 15, 2025) ‚Äì Farm Journal has announced three finalists for the prestigious 2026 Top Producer of the Year Award, honoring some of the most progressive and successful farm operations in the country. The winner and finalists will be […] The post Farm Journal Announces 2026 Top Producer Award Finalists appeared first
items.summary:
The winner and finalists will be recognized at the 2026 Top Producer Summit in Nashville, Tennessee from February 9-11. 

The three finalists are:
- Alsum Farms (Friesland, Wisconsin) - A multigenerational, 3,600-acre operation producing potatoes, pumpkins, hay, and other crops. Led by the founder and his two daughters.
- Dalton Farms (Wakeman, Ohio) - A 7th generation, 2,000-acre farm with corn, soybeans, a 400-head cattle herd, and an on-farm market. Owned by Rebecca and Edward Dalton.
- Splitter Farms (Sterling, Kansas) - A 1,400-acre row crop operation led by Matt and Janna Splitter, farming 18,500 total acres. They scaled the business after the sudden passing of Matt's father in 2010.

Additionally, the 2026 Next Generation Award winner is Tim Nuss (El Dorado Hills/Lodi, California), who farms various crops and also runs an ag tech and influencer business. The 2026 Women in Agriculture Award winner is Helle Ruddenklau (Amity, Oregon), an immigrant from Denmark who farms a diverse operation and is involved in ag advocacy.

All finalists and award winners will be recognized at the Top Producer Summit, which is sponsored by BASF, Fendt, and Pro Farmer.

items.title: Still an opportunity to attend the ICM Conference!
items.description: This year we are offering on-site registration for the Integrated Crop Managem
items.summary:
The Integrated Crop Management (ICM) Conference is taking place on December 10-11, 2025 at the Meadows Events and Conference Center in Altoona, Iowa. 

The conference will offer:
- 33 workshops covering topics like crops, pests, nutrient management, and conservation
- Up to 14 continuing education credits for Certified Crop Advisers
- Iowa Commercial Pesticide Applicator continuing instruction for 2025 in categories 1A, 1B, 1C, and 4 for an additional fee
- Invited speakers covering topics related to the Endangered Species Act, timing of corn and soybean planting, and integrated pest management for corn leafhopper and corn stunt disease

Farmers can register in-person on December 10 for this premier crop management conference. The article was written by Meaghan Anderson, a field agronomist serving nine counties in central Iowa and an extension specialist with Iowa State University Extension and Outreach.

items.title: Registration is now open for the 36th Integrated Crop Management Conference
items.description:
Join us for the 36th Integrated Crop Management Conference, which brings together a range of topics related to crop production, crop protection, nutrient management, and soil and water management. The event features experts sharing research updates and practical recommendations. Don‚Äôt miss this key opportunity for networking and education!

When: December 10 and 11, 2025

Where: The Meadows Events Center in Altoona, Iowa

Who
items.summary:
Key Summary:

The 36th Integrated Crop Management Conference will be held on December 10-11, 2025 at The Meadows Events Center in Altoona, Iowa. The conference features 33 session topics with expert speakers and covers a range of crop production, protection, nutrient management, and soil/water topics. 

Early-bird registration is $260 and ends on November 16, 2025. Regular registration is $310 until December 3, 2025. Commercial pesticide applicators can earn recertification credits in categories 1A, 1B, 1C, and 4 for an additional fee.

items.title: Purdue field day to feature research on sorghum‚Äôs value as a forage crop
items.description: Purdue University Extension will host a Forage Sorghum Field Day on Sept. 10 at the Feldun-Purdue Ag Center (FPAC) in Bedford, Indiana.
items.summary:
Purdue University Extension will host a Forage Sorghum Field Day on September 10 at the Feldun-Purdue Ag Center in Bedford, Indiana. Interested participants should register by September 5.

The event will feature research on sorghum's value as a forage crop, highlighting its advantages over corn, such as being more drought-tolerant and having lower nitrogen requirements. Attendees will learn about forage sorghum production and utilization for silage, grazing, and as a standing winter feed source.

Speakers at the event will include:
- Keith Johnson, Purdue professor of agronomy
- Mitch Tuinstra, Wickersham Chair of Excellence in Agricultural Research and scientific director of the Institute for Plant Sciences at Purdue, who will share plant breeding techniques to improve sorghum yield and quality
- Brad Shelton, FPAC superintendent
- Jason Tower, Southern Indiana Purdue Agricultural Center superintendent
- Nick Minton, Purdue Extension beef systems specialist
- Jeff Jackson, Croplan alfalfa and forage specialist

Venue tours will be available from 3-5 pm and 6-8 pm, and a dinner and bull test station tour will be offered from 5-6 pm.

items.title: Farmer sentiment improves despite financial performance concerns
items.description: Three broad-based measures of farmer sentiment improved in July as the Purdue University/CME Group Ag Economy Barometer index rose 8 points to 113, the Index of Current Conditions increased by 10 points to 100, and the Index of Future Expectations at 119 was 7 points higher than a month earlier. Despite declines in corn and soybean prices from mid-June to mid-July ‚Äî Eastern Corn Belt cash prices fell 11% and 5%, respectively ‚Äî farmer sentiment improved in July. Responses to the individual questi
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- Farmer sentiment improved in July 2024 despite concerns over financial performance. The Purdue/CME Group Ag Economy Barometer index rose 8 points to 113.

- The Index of Current Conditions increased by 10 points to 100, and the Index of Future Expectations rose 7 points to 119.

- High input costs remained the biggest concern for 34% of farmers. 29% cited the risk of lower crop and livestock prices, up from 25% in June.

- The Farm Financial Performance Index dropped 4 points in July to 81, 6 points lower than in July 2023, reflecting worries about weakening commodity prices and high input costs.

- The Farm Capital Investment Index rose 6 points in July to 38, though it remains 7 points lower than in July 2023.

- The Short-Term Farmland Value Expectations Index rose to 118 from 115 in June, while the Long-Term Farmland Value Expectations Index dropped 6 points to 146.

- 72% of crop farmer respondents expect cash rental rates to remain roughly the same as in 2024, with the remaining 15% anticipating a rise and 13% expecting a decline.

items.title: Purdue researchers adopt interdisciplinary approach to assessing emerging tar spot disease in corn
items.description: For more than a century, tar spot fungal disease in corn kept its distance from the U.S., biding its time
items.summary:
Key Findings:
- Tar spot, a fungal disease in corn, has been spreading in the U.S. since it was first detected in 2015. It has now reached 16 states and Ontario, Canada.
- Purdue researchers are taking an interdisciplinary approach, combining agricultural and engineering methods, to study the dynamics of tar spot and develop ways to monitor and assess the disease.
- The research team is using a mix of statistics, data science, epidemiology, microbiology, artificial intelligence, and computer vision, along with stakeholder feedback, to better understand tar spot.
- The research is funded by two USDA grants totaling nearly $1.1 million.
- The researchers are collaborating with experts from Colombia, Mexico, Ecuador, South Korea, and the U.S.
- Previous work by the team has included developing a digital method to quantify tar spot in corn, with promising results, but some inaccuracies still need to be addressed.
- The team is also exploring the use of drone imagery and weather data, along with traditional statistical methods, to capture details about the tar spot pathosystem.

Key Numbers/Statistics:
- Tar spot was first detected in the U.S. in 2015, affecting 2 of Indiana's 92 counties.
- By 2022, the fungus had extended to 16 states and Ontario, Canada, as well as 15 other countries in Central and South America, the Caribbean, and U.S. territories.
- The research is funded by two USDA grants totaling nearly $1.1 million.

Key Dates/Deadlines:
- The article was published on August 1, 2024.

Key Names/Organizations/Programs:
- Purdue University
- C.D. Cruz, associate professor of botany and plant pathology
- Mohammad Jahanshahi, associate professor in the Lyles School of Civil and Construction Engineering and the Elmore Family School of Electrical and Computer Engineering
- Mariela Fern√°ndez-Campos, PhD student in botany and plant pathology
- Yu-Ting Huang, postdoctoral research associate in civil engineering
- Darcy Telenko, associate professor of botany and plant pathology
- Brenden Lane, graduate student in C.D. Cruz's lab
- Sungchan Oh, computational infrastructure specialist in the Institute for Plant Sciences

Locations:
- West Lafayette, Indiana
- 16 states and Ontario, Canada
- Central and South America, the Caribbean, and U.S. territories

Context/Causes:
- Tar spot had been endemic in several Latin American countries since 1904, but had not been detected in the U.S. prior to 2015.
- The researchers are trying to understand the origins of the disease, how it has spread, and whether the pathogen in the U.S. is different from those in other countries.

Impacts for Farmers:
- The spread of tar spot in the U.S. poses a biosecurity challenge that the research aims to address with a science-based approach.
- The researchers hope that the use of high-tech data collection and analysis methods can make vital corn pathology information more widely and rapidly available to stakeholders.

Recommendations/Action Items:
- The researchers are continuing to refine their training methods to improve the accuracy and performance of their disease detection models.
- They are also working to quantify and model tar spot epidemics in production-style fields by integrating drone imagery and weather data with traditional statistical methods.

Expert Quotes:
- "There are opportunities in integrating AI-based digital technologies and point-of-care diagnostics that can provide rapid and accurate information for stakeholders," said C.D. Cruz.
- "Whether you're working on civil infrastructure health monitoring or agricultural disease epidemiology, you can have a profound impact not only on humans but also on the environment," said Mohammad Jahanshahi.

items.title: ISA will host sheep-themed educational opportunities and competitions at Indiana State Fair
items.description: In addition to 4-H and open sheep shows, the Indiana Sheep Association (ISA) is sponsoring sheep-themed competitions, vendors and educational opportunities at this year‚Äôs Indiana State Fair, with additional support from the Indiana Sheep and Wool Market Development Program (IN SW).
items.summary:
The Indiana Sheep Association (ISA), with support from the Indiana Sheep and Wool Market Development Program (IN S&W), is hosting various sheep-themed events and competitions at the 2024 Indiana State Fair:

- The Wool and Ewe Room and Ewe2 boutique will be open throughout the fair, offering woolen products, livestock-themed apparel, jewelry, and more.
- On August 2 at 10 a.m., there will be an open wool judging and wool sale event in the Blue Ribbon Pavilion.
- The Make It With Wool (MIWW) competition and fashion show will take place on August 4 at 2 p.m. in the Indiana Arts Building.
- The Indiana State Fair Shearing Contest will be held on August 4 at 5 p.m. in the Ball State University Champions Pavilion.
- From August 8-11 from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m., the Taste from Indiana Farms event in the Indiana Farm Bureau Fall Creek Pavilion will offer free samples of Indiana lamb.
- The annual Sheep to Shawl competition, where youth teams create a wool shawl from scratch, will be on August 18 at 10 a.m. in the Indiana Arts Building.

The ISA President, Jane Smith, stated that the association is proud to bring the spirit of the sheep industry to the fair, with the theme of "Art and Nature" showcasing sheep-related art from Indiana artists.

items.description: The Indiana State Fair kicks off Aug. 2 and highlights the theme ‚ÄúThe Art Nature of Fun‚Äù in collaboration with Newfields. items.title: Potassium Cycle now available!

items.summary: The University of Wisconsin-Madison has released a new publication called "Potassium Cycle" that provides a visual overview of the potassium cycle in Wisconsin cropping systems. The two-page publication outlines key potassium concepts and recommendations for specific situations. The publication is available for download only and was announced on June 12, 2024 in the Wisconsin Crop Manager newsletter.

items.title: Wisconsin Winter Wheat Update
items.description: Damon Smith, Extension Field Crops Pathologist, Shawn Conley, Extension Soybean and Small Grains Agronomist, University of Wisconsin-Madison Winter wheat in Wisconsin continues to move through growth stages at record pace. We are about 10-14 days …
items.summary:
Wisconsin Winter Wheat Update:

- Wisconsin winter wheat is 10-14 days ahead of typical growth stages due to a warm spring and timely rainfall.
- There is a high likelihood of stripe rust appearing in Wisconsin this season, but it has not been detected yet. Farmers are advised to scout their fields and report any findings.
- Fusarium head blight (FHB) is expected to be an issue this season due to moderate temperatures and adequate precipitation, in contrast with recent hot and dry spring seasons.
- FHB can limit yields and produce the mycotoxin deoxynivalenol (DON or vomitoxin), which can lead to discounts or rejection at the elevator if levels exceed 2 ppm in the finished grain.
- Farmers are encouraged to manage FHB, as it is a yield-limiting disease worth addressing.
- The update was provided by Damon Smith, Extension Field Crops Pathologist, and Shawn Conley, Extension Soybean and Small Grains Agronomist, from the University of Wisconsin-Madison.
- The article was posted on May 20, 2024 on the UW Madison website.

items.title: Questions to consider prior to replanting a soybean field
items.description: Shawn P. Conley, Soybean and Small Grains Specialist, UW-Madison Early in the growing season, abiotic (freezing temperatures, hail, flooding, etc.) and biotic (slugs, deer, disease, insects, etc.) factors often reduce soybean plant stands. A soybean …
items.summary:
Soybean plants have the ability to compensate for open spaces by developing additional branches and pods, allowing them to yield well even with lower plant stands. However, action should be considered if stand loss leaves fewer than 50,000-60,000 evenly-distributed plants per acre in southern regions, or 75,000 plants per acre in northern regions, or if there are areas larger than 6-10 square feet without any plants. 

Factors to evaluate when considering replanting include the existing plant stand, distribution, and ability to recover; planting date and relative maturity; weed management; seed and variety availability; cost and insurance; and the tradeoff between a suboptimal stand vs. yield penalty from delayed replanting. The article recommends closely assessing fields for plant loss and patterns before deciding whether to replant.

An additional resource is provided for more information on soybean replant decisions.

items.title: Spraying 2,4-D on Soybean in 2024?
items.description: Daniel H. Smith, Outreach Program Manager, UW-Madison Division of Extension, Rodrigo Werle, Weed Scientist and Extension Specialist, UW-Madison Are you planning to spray 2,4-D for postemergence broadleaf weed control in Enlist E3 soybean? The 2,4-D …
items.summary:
Key points:

1. The only labeled formulation for postemergence broadleaf weed control in Enlist E3 soybeans is the 2,4-D choline formulation present in Enlist One and Enlist Duo herbicides. 2,4-D ester and amine formulations cannot be used.

2. There have been reports of producers, agronomists, and Certified Crop Advisors considering using the ester or amine formulations for postemergence applications, which is not allowed.

3. Regarding burndown applications, if using a 2,4-D ester or amine formulation product, the soybean plant back interval (minimum of 7 days when using 0.5 lbs ae/acre) must be respected.

4. If planting Enlist E3 soybeans, Enlist One or Enlist DUO can be applied without the plant back restriction.

The article was posted on May 11, 2024 by Daniel H. Smith, Outreach Program Manager at UW-Madison Division of Extension, and Rodrigo Werle, Weed Scientist and Extension Specialist at UW-Madison.

items.title: Wisconsin CCA Board Election Results
items.description: Thank you to everyone who provided nominations and voted in the recent Wisconsin CCA Board election. On-behalf of the election process I would like to welcome Rob Shields, Matt Brugger, and Chris Bandura to the …
items.summary: The Wisconsin CCA (Certified Crop Adviser) Board election results have been posted. Rob Shields, Matt Brugger, and Chris Bandura have been elected to the WI CCA Board and are eligible to serve two, three-year terms. All WI CCAs in good standing status are eligible for nomination and can vote in future elections, which will take place in early 2025. Daniel H. Smith, the Outreach Program Manager for the Crops and Soils Program at the University of Wisconsin-Madison Division of Extension, oversees the election process.
